title: Oracle Invocation Summoner
llm_judge_instructions: Evaluate the Invocation Blueprint based on task modeling, tool contracts, grounding, and observability. Ensure realistic engineering practices are followed.

dimensions.label: Task Modeling & Decomposition
dimensions.description: Does the blueprint turn messy user questions into a clear, multi-step plan?

bands.label: Vague or Flat
bands.criteria: Barely decomposes tasks. Treats complex queries as a single step or leaves the plan implicit. Examples: Says 'the agent will just answer' without substeps. Makes no distinction between steps needing tools vs pure reasoning.

bands.label: Partial Decomposition
bands.criteria: Shows some structure (e.g., parse -> search -> answer) but misses key branches or cases. Examples: Has a basic 2-3 step flow but no decision points. Does not fully address mixed questions.

bands.label: Clear, Intent-Aware Plan
bands.criteria: Provides a crisp plan with explicit stages, decision points, and separation of concerns. Examples: Describes how the agent parses user intent into sub-queries. Separates planning from execution.

dimensions.label: Tool Contracts & Invocation Logic
dimensions.description: Are tools well-defined and called with clear rules, avoiding flailing?

bands.label: Hand-Wavy Tools
bands.criteria: Defines tools loosely or not at all. Invocation rules are unclear or obviously flawed. Examples: Mentions 'search' without specifying inputs/outputs. No mapping from task types to specific tools.

bands.label: Defined but Imperfect
bands.criteria: Tools are defined with some structure, but invocation logic is incomplete or brittle. Examples: Good schemas, but ambiguous about when to call each tool. Does not clarify how tool results are combined.

bands.label: Crisp Contracts & Intentional Calls
bands.criteria: Tools have clear contracts and are invoked through explicit, sensible rules. Examples: Each tool has a well-defined purpose, inputs, and outputs. The flow encodes when to call which tool based on user intent.

dimensions.label: Grounding & Guardrails
dimensions.description: Does the design minimize hallucinations and enforce good grounding behaviors?

bands.label: Weak Grounding
bands.criteria: Little to no guidance on when the agent must use tools. Hallucinations are likely. Examples: Agent is free to answer from 'general knowledge' for time-sensitive questions. No policies for checking metrics.

bands.label: Basic Guardrails
bands.criteria: Some grounding rules exist but are incomplete or underspecified. Examples: Requires tool calls in some scenarios but misses key cases. Mentions error handling but does not specify behaviors.

bands.label: Strong Grounding & Safety
bands.criteria: The design strongly nudges the agent toward grounded answers and handles failures safely. Examples: Explicit rules like 'always use repo_search for repo-related questions'. Protocols for tool timeouts/retries.

dimensions.label: Observability & Maintainability
dimensions.description: Can other engineers debug, operate, and evolve this agent?

bands.label: Opaque
bands.criteria: Little or no mention of logging, tracing, or configuration. The system would be hard to debug. Examples: No logs beyond generic 'agent started'. No way to trace tool calls for a request.

bands.label: Partially Observable
bands.criteria: Some observability ideas are present, but the story is incomplete. Examples: Logs tool calls but not user intent or intermediate state. Mentions metrics without specifying what to measure.

bands.label: Operator-Friendly Design
bands.criteria: Provides a coherent plan for logging, metrics, and configuration. Examples: Describes structured logs for user intent, plan, and tool calls. Defines key metrics (e.g. tool_call_count).
